headline: A Striking ’70s Design in Australia
summary: The owner restored this Melbourne-area home with an updated kitchen, refurbished columns and floors and midcentury furniture to complete the retro look.

headline: Court Rules Gay Employees Can Sue Under 1964 Civil Rights Act
summary: A federal appeals court ruled Tuesday that a landmark civil rights law allows gay employees to sue their employers for discrimination on the basis of their sexual orientation.

headline: Japan’s Bunch of New Tech Ideas Includes Nine Breeds of Carrots
summary: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe says he wants to turn the food business, where Japan has a $70 billion annual trade deficit, into an export-growth sector along the lines of high-speed rail and carbon-fiber materials.

headline: Top Russian Space Official Praises Reusable Rocket Technology
summary: Igor Komarov, director general of Roscosmos, lauded Elon Musk’s SpaceX for developing reusable rockets and said his country has been working on a variant of that approach to remain competitive.

headline: Former Trump Adviser Acknowledges Involvement in Russian Spy Case
summary: Former Trump campaign adviser Carter Page confirmed he was the unnamed American consultant targeted for recruitment by Russian intelligence officers in a high-profile spy case.

headline: Cuomo, Lawmakers Clash Over Budget
summary: New York State Assembly Speaker Carl Heastie and Gov. Andrew Cuomo clashed over the urgency of passing the state’s $160 billion spending plan.

headline: Ecuador National Electoral Council Says Vote Results Are Irreversible
summary: Ecuador’s national electoral council said Tuesday that the results of the country’s presidential vote are irreversible, giving ruling party candidate Lenin Moreno the victory.

headline: NFL and Amazon Reach One-Year Streaming Deal For About $50 Million
summary: The National Football League has reached a deal to stream 10 Thursday night games with Amazon.com, the online retailer that is aggressively trying to position itself as premier source of entertainment content

headline: Mar-a-Lago Summit Aims to Air, Not Resolve, China-U.S. Issues
summary: When President Donald Trump hosts Chinese president Xi Jinping at his Mar-a-Lago club for a 24-hour “introductory” summit on Thursday, he aims to exchange views on sensitive issues like North Korea and trade rather than resolve them, senior White House officials say.

headline: Amazon, FTC End Legal Battle, Clearing the Way for up to $70 Million in Refunds
summary: The FTC said that the process of refunding customers for eligible transactions made between November 2011 and May 2016 will begin shortly.

headline: Sprint to End 50% Discount Plan
summary: Sprint Corp. is dropping one of its most aggressive promotions: a long-running offer to charge half the price of certain rival plans to get customers to switch.

headline: McDonald’s U.S. Marketing Chief to Leave
summary: Deborah Wahl, McDonald’s top marketer in the U.S., will leave the company as part of another management shakeup aimed at reviving the burger chain’s fortunes.

headline: Mr. Trump Meets Mr. Xi
summary: China’s strongman will be taking the measure of the new President.

headline: Terror Returns to Russia
summary: Vladimir Putin propped up Bashar Assad instead of fighting Islamic State.

headline: The U.S. Needs a New China Debate
summary: The status quo may not be sustainable, but conflict isn’t inevitable.

headline: The FDA Can Declare War on Alzheimer’s
summary: Flexible standards for drug approval would help patients.

headline: Trump Says He’ll Work With Democrats. Will They Work With Him?
summary: Under Obama, the GOP thrived through conflict. The other party looks to be following that example.

headline: The Challenge at Mar-a-Lago: Wooing China to Drop Its Tariffs
summary: Beijing joined the WTO in 2001 on terms that no longer make sense for an industrial powerhouse.

headline: NotableQuotable: Bernie and the Elites
summary: ‘Is attacking liberal elitism really the proper strategy for the opposition to Trump?’

headline: NJ Transit Derailment Exposes Chronic Problems
summary: Hopes of regular train service to and from New York Penn Station were dashed Tuesday afternoon as it became clear that Monday’s minor derailment of an NJ Transit train created major damage within the station.

headline: House Approves Bill to Ease Employee Stock Rules
summary: Startups and other privately held companies would have greater flexibility in awarding stock to employees without triggering what critics say are overly intrusive reporting requirements, under legislation passed by the U.S. House Tuesday.

headline: Chemical Attack in Syria Puts Focus on Trump Policy
summary: Graphic images of dead and dying Syrian children following Tuesday’s suspected chemical attack are forcing the Trump administration to confront the war just days after officials signaled the U.S. would no longer demand that Syrian President Bashar al-Assad leave power.

headline: Syngenta-ChemChina Deal Gets U.S. Regulatory Clearance
summary: U.S. antitrust officials cleared China National Chemical Corp.’s purchase of Swiss pesticide giant Syngenta AG, requiring that ChemChina sell three crop chemical businesses to a rival.

headline: Shoe Retailer Payless Files for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy
summary: Payless ShoeSource Inc., one of country’s largest shoe retailers, filed for bankruptcy Tuesday, the latest big brick-and-mortar chain to succumb to declining traffic and the proliferation of online shopping.

headline: Economists Predict Modest Shrinkage In Fed’s Balance Sheet
summary: As Federal Reserve officials prepare their strategy for shrinking the central bank’s $4.5 trillion portfolio of bonds and other assets, one key question is just how much smaller those holdings should be.

headline: Debating a Basic Guaranteed Income for All
summary: Regarding Marc Levinson’s review of Philippe Van Parijs and Yannick Vanderborght’s “Basic Income”: Once you institute a government-provided basic income, a new special interest group will appear, and the basic income will morph into a monster.

headline: Tax Reform Won’t Yield a 1980s-Style Boom
summary: Prof. Robert Barro cites the favorable experience for economic growth and employment with the Reagan tax cuts in the 1980s. However, he fails to remind us that when those tax cuts were made U.S. unemployment was high and the public debt to GDP ratio was low.

headline: Battle Over Gorsuch Confirmation Is Set to Hit Senate Floor
summary: The Senate is barreling toward a showdown over the confirmation of Supreme Court nominee Neil Gorsuch, as Republican Leader Mitch McConnell said Tuesday he has enough votes to change the Senate rules and eliminate the filibuster.

headline: This Immigrant Problem Is More Imagined Than Real
summary: Go volunteer at your local school and meet some of the immigrant kids, go to community gatherings and meet the parents. You will be pleasantly surprised.

headline: UAW Political Spending Way Down in 2016
summary: The United Auto Workers union said it spent $13.2 million in political activities last year, down sharply from the $29.9 million spent in 2012 during President Barack Obama’s re-election campaign

headline: Barred From Passing Laws, Venezuelan Opposition Lawmakers Take to the Streets
summary: After revoking a takeover of congress, President Nicolás Maduro celebrated Venezuela as “a powerful democracy.” But on Tuesday, he doubled down on political foes, deploying thousands of police officers and soldiers across the capital against an opposition march.

headline: Jamie Dimon: Time to ‘Open Up the Rulebook’
summary: J.P. Morgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon laid out his wishlist of regulatory changes in his annual shareholder letter, calling for simpler and better-coordinated rules that could help to spur more lending and in turn economic growth.

headline: Talk to the Freedom Caucus
summary: The White House tries again to assemble a House majority on health insurance.

headline: Democratic Lawmakers See Window for Bipartisan Action Closing
summary: Democratic lawmakers who may be willing to work with President Donald Trump have met with Republican officials, while saying that the window for bipartisan action is rapidly closing.

headline: Power and Politics at the Armory
summary: This reimagining of the Old Vic production of Eugene O’Neill’s play is striking in look and tone, and flirts with being agitprop.

headline: Third Woman Joins Racial Discrimination Suit Against Fox News
summary: A third black employee of Fox News has joined a lawsuit accusing the news network, some of its executives and parent company 21st Century Fox of racial discrimination.

headline: A Pimco Fund Just Became the Biggest Active Bond Fund, and It Wasn’t Bill Gross’s
summary: Pimco’s Income Fund had $79.1 billion in assets under management as of March 31, one of several recent victories for the $1.5 trillion money manager as it tries to move beyond the most tumultuous period in its history.

headline: Oil Prices Rise on Continued OPEC Bet
summary: Oil prices rose to a four-week high as traders continued to bet that cuts from the world’s biggest exporters and the coming high-demand season are ending oversupply in the market.

headline: U.S. Dollar, Yen Rise on Investor Caution
summary: The dollar and Japanese yen rose as investors shied away from riskier assets ahead of important data and a summit between U.S. and Chinese leaders.

headline: New Hotel Will Be Priciest on California Coast, Retail Mogul Says
summary: Retail mogul Rick Caruso has hired a prominent hotel industry executive as his multibillion-dollar real-estate company makes its first push into the resort business with the five-star Rosewood Miramar Beach Montecito on the California coast.

headline: White House Blames Obama ‘Weakness’ for New Syria Attack
summary: President Donald Trump on Tuesday condemned the suspected chemical attack in Syria that killed at least 58 people, calling it a result of the Obama administration’s “weakness” in confronting the Assad regime.

headline: Metals: Gold Gains on Weak U.S. Data
summary: Gold prices rose Tuesday, boosted by weaker-than-expected U.S. data some analysts said could slow the pace of interest-rate increases.

headline: U.S. 10-Year Yield Hits Lowest Point in Over a Month
summary: U.S. government bonds reversed earlier price gains to trade little changed Tuesday as investors took some chips off the table.

headline: New Rules to Make Globalization Work
summary: Focus on fiscal discipline and rules-based policy making to make the global economy run smoothly.

headline: AIG on Track Despite Turmoil at the Top
summary: AIG’s own targets remain in sight even as it searches for a new chief executive.

headline: Economy Will Miss That New-Car Smell
summary: Slowing car sales may not be replaced by other consumer spending, which would weigh on the economy.

headline: Staples Deal: Does the Good Outweigh the Bad?
summary: Staples’s business serving corporate customers could make it more interesting to a private-equity buyer, but they would still have to contend with retail declines.

headline: Gold, Yen, Bonds Gain as Investors Step Up Safety Plays
summary: Havens like U.S. government bonds, gold and the Japanese yen are rallying, highlighting an undercurrent of investor worry in an otherwise buoyant market.

headline: Why Contrarians Won’t Clean Up in Bed Bath & Beyond
summary: Bed Bath & Beyond’s shares are trading near their lowest level since September 2010 and analysts don’t see an end to the slump.

headline: Cargo Owners Complain of ‘Total Mess’ Shipping Goods to Asia
summary: The launch of two global container shipping alliances this week has gotten off to a rough start, with cargo owners in Europe complaining of long delays to carry goods to Asia.

headline: Congo Refugee Rebuilds His Life in Connecticut
summary: Fleeing death threats, Joshua Mahinanda Kangere left behind 10 children and a nursing job in the Congo to build a new life in the U.S. He is hoping to save enough money working as a dishwasher in a Connecticut restaurant to buy a car and eventually return to nursing.

headline: Photos of the Day: April 4
summary: In photos selected Tuesday by Wall Street Journal editors, cherry blossoms bloom in Shanghai, Syrian children are treated after a suspected chemical attack, North Carolina celebrates its national championship win in college basketball, and more.

headline: GOP Is Testing Health-Law Tweaks for Conservative Appeal
summary: Republican legislators are weighing a health-care proposal aimed at winning over House conservatives that would allow states to opt-out of some requirements in the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Carlyle Group’s Sequa Corp. Kicks Off Debt Restructuring
summary: Sequa Corp. launched a long-awaited deal to refinance $1.25 billion in term loans and revolver drawings maturing in June as part of a broader restructuring aimed at keeping the aerospace and industrial manufacturer out of chapter 11, according to a person familiar with the matter.

headline: Tesla Shares Surpass $300
summary: Tesla, which overtook Ford as the second-largest U.S. auto maker by market value, continued its run by eclipsing $300-a-share for the first time and closing the gap with GM.

headline: Idlib Attack Aimed at Disrupting Talks, U.N.’s Syria Envoy Says
summary: At the request of France and the U.K., the U.N. Security Council schedules an emergency session to discuss the assault.

headline: Tony Romo Retires, Heads to Broadcast Booth
summary: The oft-injured Pro-Bowl quarterback will not seek starting role on another team and instead replace Phil Simms at CBS

headline: Spec House on San Francisco’s Gold Coast Seeks $40 Million
summary: In Pacific Heights, the home is near the homes of Oracle billionaire Larry Ellison, Apple Chief Design Officer Jony Ive and philanthropists Ann and Gordon Getty.

headline: California Race Features a Cast of Two Dozen Contenders
summary: Voters in California’s 34th congressional district will pick from a field of 24 contenders vying for the same congressional seat—among them a former undocumented immigrant, an Obama White House official and a former public schoolteacher.

headline: Retail Property Market Held Steady in First Quarter
summary: The national retail-property market held steady in the first quarter as vacancy rates in shopping centers increased in 28 of 77 U.S. metro areas, a slight improvement from the fourth quarter, when 30 metro areas recorded year-over-year increases.

headline: ‘Pokémon Go’ Suit Makes Case for Virtual Trespassing
summary: Annoyed homeowners say “Pokémon Go” players have gone too far in their quest to master the smartphone game—and they want the company behind the hit application to be held responsible.

headline: A Guide to the Other Side of Marfa
summary: A closer look at the natural side of this small West Texas town.

headline: More 401(k) Plans Turn to Managed Accounts for Autoenrolled Workers
summary: Target-date funds, the default investment in most 401(k) plans, attract about have of the money that flows into employer-sponsored retirement plans. That prevalence faces pressure.

headline: Ralph Lauren to Close One of Its Main New York Stores
summary: Ralph Lauren plans to shutter one of its main stores in Manhattan and realign its e-commerce operations, as the struggling New York fashion house continues to push its turnaround plan.

headline: NCAA to Consider North Carolina for Future Championships
summary: The NCAA board of governors said it will consider North Carolina as a host for championships now that lawmakers have dialed back a controversial bathroom law.

headline: Golfer Annie Park’s Childhood Dilemma
summary: The LPGA pro had to choose between Korean dance and golf; she went with her passion for the sport

headline: Hedge Fund Sound Point Sells Stake to Neuberger Berman
summary: Hedge fund Sound Point Capital agreed to sell a minority stake to Neuberger Berman‘s Dyal Capital arm.

headline: Exxon Eyes Brazil Expansion
summary: Exxon Mobil is in talks to gain access to Brazil’s prized deep-water resources.

headline: AmTrust Revises Earnings From Last Three Years
summary: AmTrust Financial Services revised its last three years’ worth of earnings downward by about $136 million because of accounting errors.

headline: Roxane Gay Picks ‘Tumbling’ for WSJ Book Club
summary: Roxane Gay chooses Diane McKinney-Whetstone’s debut, ‘Tumbling,’ a novel set in Philadelphia in the 1940s and ’50s, for The Wall Street Journal Book Club.

headline: Seadrill Warns of ’Likely’ Bankruptcy Filing in U.S. or U.K.
summary: Offshore drilling services company Seadrill Ltd. said it is planning a comprehensive debt restructuring that will likely include a bankruptcy filing in the U.S. or the U.K.

headline: Syrian Town Stricken by Suspected Chemical Attack
summary: A suspected chemical attack killed dozens in a rebel-held town in northwestern Syria, according to rescue workers and an opposition monitoring group.

headline: Hard to Figure How Corporate Bonds Rally From Here
summary: Corporate bonds have had a strong run in the past year. There is little room for further gains.

headline: The Ugliest National Championship Ever?
summary: North Carolina’s win over Gonzaga was highlighted by fouls, foul shots, bricks, reviews, more fouls.

headline: Canada Posts Surprise Trade Deficit in February
summary: Canada unexpectedly swung back into a trade deficit in February, ending three straight months of surpluses, on a broad-based decline in exports.

headline: A Watershed Moment in CEO Activism
summary: The White House’s initial travel ban sparked an unusually strong response from companies and their chiefs; to one communications firm, it signals the rise of a new kind of CEO activism.

headline: Barclays Africa Exit Looking Like Good Timing
summary: Barclay’s decision a year ago to sell its African subsidiary, among the group’s most profitable businesses, still looks on track despite financial ructions in its biggest market, South Africa.

headline: U.S. Shows China How the Sausage Is Made
summary: A meat factory in central China is at the forefront of a shift in how the country is using Western practices and technology to advance its economy.

headline: Schools Rack Their Brains as Bus Driver Jobs Go Begging
summary: The Wake County, N.C., school district is one of many that are struggling to recruit and retain an adequate supply of school-bus drivers amid declining unemployment and rising wages.

headline: How Boards Should Talk About Cyberrisk
summary: High-profile data breaches leading to class-action lawsuits, executive dismissals, and reduced company valuations have convinced corporate boards to put a higher value on cybersecurity.

headline: South African Trade Unions Call for Zuma to Resign
summary: South Africa’s powerful federation of trade unions on Tuesday called on President Jacob Zuma to step down, becoming the latest ally of the ruling African National Congress to abandon the embattled president.

headline: Toshiba to Buy Engie’s Stake in U.K. Nuclear Venture
summary: Toshiba will buy out partner Engie’s 40% stake in the operator of a proposed U.K. nuclear power project for $138 million after Engie asked for the step under the terms of their contract.

headline: The 10-Point: Gerard Baker on the Gorsuch standoff, China currency moves, Tesla overtaking Ford and more
summary: A personal, guided tour to the best scoops and stories every day in The Wall Street Journal, from Editor in Chief Gerard Baker.

headline: Banks Turn to Virtual World to Modernize Commodities Trading
summary: Banks and traders are experimenting with the technology behind bitcoin in an effort to solve longstanding problems in the trading of physical commodities.

headline: Gillette, Bleeding Market Share, Cuts Prices of Razors
summary: Razor giant Gillette—which has been losing market share for six straight years—is slashing its prices as it fends off startups Dollar Shave Club and Harry’s, which together have grabbed 12.2% of the U.S. market.

headline: Photos: Blast Hits Subway in St. Petersburg, Russia
summary: A blast ripped through a subway train in St. Petersburg on Monday, killing multiple people and inuring more than 20.

headline: Some Marketers Want More Ad Testing, Less Debating About Metrics
summary: Some performance marketers, such as Airbnb and Wayfair, are contrarians when it comes to the digital ad industry’s push to emphasize viewability and TV-like metrics.

headline: Germany’s Housing Boom a Boon for Developers
summary: Development of middle-class housing in Germany is increasing, but the pace isn’t fast enough to meet booming demand.

headline: When Your Employer Plans Your Baby Shower
summary: Companies have been adding benefits for working parents as they seek to hang on to employees balancing family and work. One of the latest is Fifth Third’s maternity concierge service, which helps mothers with stroller recommendations, day-care options and more.

headline: Boeing Adds Seat Deals to Smooth Out Supply Chain
summary: The jet maker has entered into more agreements with aircraft-seat makers in an effort to break up supply-chain logjams as it ramps up production.

headline: U.S. Factory Activity Continued to Expand in March
summary: U.S. factory activity decelerated slightly in March but continued to expand at a solid pace, signaling healthy momentum in the nation’s manufacturing sector.

headline: U.S. Companies Expected to Post Strongest Quarter Since 2011
summary: U.S. companies are poised to report their strongest quarterly earnings in years, potentially building on the stock market’s rally. However, disappointing results could reignite concerns that stock-price gains have outpaced earnings growth.

headline: U.S. Stocks Buoyed by Manufacturing, Energy Sectors
summary: U.S. stock indexes edged higher, led by a rise in shares of manufacturers. Meanwhile, shares of financial companies in the S&P 500 fell 0.2%.

headline: Dozens Dead in Syria Chemical Attack
summary: A suspected chemical attack widely blamed on the Syrian regime killed at least 58 people in an opposition-held town Tuesday, days after the Trump administration signaled the U.S. would no longer demand that Syrian President Bashar al-Assad leave power.

headline: Uber Self-Driving Program Hits Another Pothole
summary: Pittsburgh’s mayor is pressing Uber to give back more to the community that lets the ride-hailing firm use public roads to test its autonomous driving technology, marking the latest challenge for the embattled startup.

headline: Boeing Agrees to First Plane Sale to Iran Under Trump
summary: Boeing agreed to sell up to 60 of its most popular jets to an Iranian airline, doubling down on the country amid uncertainty over the Trump administration’s tolerance for U.S. business dealings in Iran.
